reviewText:
I have tried a few of these tuna snack packs. They are convenient for take-along and just the right size for a snack or quick lunch.

The rosemary garlic is new to me. It tastes fine, but is much more sweet than sea-salty.  If I didn't know it flavored with rosemary and garlic, I would never have guessed. Rosemary has a very distinctive taste, and I definitely wasn't feeling it.

This variety of Bumble Bee snack is still pretty good, but prepare to be disappointed if you are hoping for that characteristic rosemary flavor.

This is definitely a snack rather than a meal.  The box holds a 2.75 oz. tin of tuna salad with a peel-off foil top and a sleeve of 6 crackers at 0.10 oz. each for a total of 3.35 oz.  There is a lot of packaging material for such little food, including a plastic spoon.  Small children could be convinced that it is astronaut food and would enjoy it with one of those little mylar pouches of fruit punch that has a short, pointed straw stuck to the side.

The tuna salad does not have large chunks of tuna and noticeable bits of celery as shown in the photograph on the box.  It is moist and has a smooth texture except for some bits of cooked celery and water chestnut.  It is not at all fishy but surprisingly sweet and bland, with just a hint of rosemary.  It tastes like it has sweet relish in it, but does not.  It does not taste particularly salty and the garlic is undetectable.  It would benefit from some black pepper.

There is plenty of tuna salad for each cracker.  The crackers have a mild flavor and are slightly crisp, like a generic Ritz cracker.

The snack contains 21 g of fat, 7 g of protein, and 20 g of carbohydrates, as well as 445 mg of sodium and 300 calories.
emergency rations (i.e. no electricity and so on) not much there to eat. fine for a toddler
BETTER THAN NOTHING

I thought that the cracker would be bigger, like the kind that is fitting in the palm of your hand.  These are smaller more like the size of Ritz crackers or regular saltine crackers. The crackers are really good btw.  The tuna salad was sweeter than expected.  The bits of some kind of vegetable was not really a good choice because it might possibly have been better just with tuna.  The sweetness to me was a put off because I normally enjoy a more savory tuna with added celery and diced onion with salt, pepper, and olive oil mayonnaise.  So I am going back to basics and making my own tuna salad.  No big deal, but I thought this might be good to take to the park for picnics or summer car trips.  It was a good idea, but just wasn't for me.
summary: Good idea, just too sweet for me

reviewText:
I'd rate the beef vegetable Reduced Sodium as okay. I'd like it better if the broth didn't have that strange texture (like you get when you buy canned gravy). The chunks of carrot and potato are nice, but this really needed more of the veggies. A lot of broth (in that odd gravy texture) on this one. It's reduced sodium, but still VERY salty to the taste.

I bought this to have on hand for cold/flu season. I'm not crazy about it, but we wanted a non-chicken soup for variety for emergencies and didn't want a high calorie or superhigh salt one. So, this is serviceable. If they cut down the salt more, fixed that odd texture thing, and added more veggies, this would be 4 stars+.

But really, it's not that bad. And for this time of year when a cold can lay you flat and you can't cook, good to have handy.
summary: Okay--still too salty and the broth texture is odd--needs more veggies

reviewText: I like that this soup is gluten free, has no added MSG and no artificial flavors. I also like that it has a pull-top lid as this makes it convenient for a quick microwave lunch option at the office. This soup is flavored with bacon and that's always a plus in my book. However, I still can't report that I like this soup. I don't dislike it either and that's why I gave it a three star "it's okay" rating. If there was a different soup option available in my pantry I would pick up that can instead of this one. In terms of cream-based chowder soups I prefer Progresso Traditional Soup, New England Clam Chowder, 18.5 Oz. I ordered this in October of 2014 and paid $1.50 for the 18.5 oz can. This was included as an item in a Prime Pantry order and all items arrived in good condition.

Also, too salty needs to be water down or else is fine. Opting for another flavor. Please increase stock to carry the Light Soups, very little selections.
Thank you

I first tasted Progresso New England Clam Chowder while visiting a Costco store. They were giving away tiny paper cups of it. I suspect I was pretty hungry at the time. In any case, it tasted quite good and I ended up buying a pack of about a dozen cans, which was probably one of those impulse-item mistakes. We stock up on a number of items like this to have food on hand for "emergency" purposes when forgetting to go to the grocery store. Plus it's an item that might be useful on camping trips.

The clam chowder is OK, but I wouldn't rank it among the better ones i've had. It's rather pasty, somewhat tasteless and the clams seem rather sparse. It will work in an emergency, and that's how we treat it. I'd say the sodium content is much too high and the protein content is not high enough. It's just not the best soup. Well our other use was for camping. After a long day of hiking, etc., it's real easy to prepare and, man, it can taste mighty good out in the open air. Well, I have mixed feelings about this product. I'm not strongly negative, but I don't think I'd buy it again.

Gary Peterson

Progresso Traditional Soup, Chicken & Sausage Gumbo, 19 Oz (538g), by  Progresso.
This canned gumbo contains just about everything under the sun, but does not measure up to the gumbo that I get at the Legal Seafoods Restaurant, or even to the other Progresso soups, like the New England Clam Chowder.  This is a work in progress. To start with, it is spoiled by 1300mg of salt per can, the amount of salt that you would get in three hotdogs, and making it just about impossible to finish the can in one sitting. It is almost like drinking seawater. This soup is not for anyone on a low salt diet, like anyone with high blood pressure or water retention problems.  Comparing this canned gumbo to a restaurant gumbo, is something like comparing vegetable soup to gazpacho or salsa. The fresh taste and quality is just not there yet. Give them time to get it right. Two and a half stars, rounded off to three stars for at least trying to get it right.

reviewText: When it comes to convenience and ease of use, nothing beats a can of soup. There is so much you can do with it. I purchased this primarily for consuming as soup. reviewText: Not great soup but okay

I find this makes a great base for my version of New England Clam Chowder. I say base because I doctor the soup with a can of chopped clams. A 5 ounce can of any brand chopped clams improves the soup tremendously. Unfortunately the soup should be labeled New England Potato and Clam Chowder. All good chowder will have diced potato but unfortunately Progresso got carried away with the spuds. There is another ingredient I sometimes add and that is a bacon bits.  Real bacon adds that extra flavor to make the chowder to give it that real chowder taste. Fortunately there is a manufacturer that has real bacon bits. Just add a teaspoon along with the extra clams while the chowder is simmering on low heat. Heat the chowder slowly so the extra clams and the real bacon bits have a chance to add the extra flavor. I believe chopped clams and the real bacon bits are available here at Amazon.

reviewText: My husband wasn't too impressed with the taste of these.

I am from Australia and have only had cornbread when eating in restaurants. This was my first experience with a packet home mix and I was a bit disappointed.

I made cornbread muffins from the mix, and it was easy to make with just adding oil, egg and milk. The muffins were quick to cook and rose nicely.

However, the taste and texture wasn't as I had hoped. They weren't very flavorsome, even adding butter to them, and the texture was a little on the dry side. This became more obvious once they had cooled.......they were at their best fresh from the oven.

This isn't a bad, easy-to-make cornbread. But the taste and texture did leave a little to be desired. I would probably buy again and try experimenting with the added ingredients to see if I could spice them up a bit.
summary: Mixed feelings - not bad, but not great

These are probably only a good option if you are flexible about food, and don't mind switching from flat-bottomed tacos to taco salad if yours end up mostly in pieces like mine.

This was my first time trying Stagg Chili.  I was excited to try it, because I like to make chili myself, but sometimes it is just convenient to open up a can.  My favorite is Van Camp's which I grew up eating, but I can't always find it anymore.  I was disappointed to find out that Hormel made this, because I do not like their regular chili at all.  This one is, at least, better quality in appearance than their regular chili.  The meat looked like meat, and these beans were cooked just right.
To me, this is a very tomato based chili, with a good mixture of beans to meat, and a bit light on the onion.  I find it a bit watery to use on hot dogs and chili cheese fries, which are my main reasons for opening up a can of chili.
I probably won't order it again, but I didn't dislike it.  It's just ok.

reviewText:
ETA  Ok in fairness, I reviewed this product yesterday,  I was not impressed with the rice at first serving,
BUT Today, I opened up the rice container and what hits me in the nose is Basmati aroma, Why this rice didn't smell like this last evening after cooking is beyond me. I didn't have any other strong cooking orders going on at the time.
Today the scent was very pleasant. Identifiably Basmati.  I heated a bowl with some Siraracha and a sprinkle of parm cheese and other than the rice being slightly underdone and a bit al dente it was pretty good. The flavor had time to develop overnight (I guess) and it was pretty good.
It didn't have that cardboardy taste this afternoon,  So I'm thinking I need to increase the amount of water slightly and see what that does.
I just wished it tasted like it did today last night.

We eat a lot of rice in our household, many types from Black rice to off the shelf cheapy stuff.
This Lundberg Basmati rice had a lot of green rice and some husks, it was clean though, there was no clouding of the water as I was washing it.
I used the recommended amount of water and a bit of butter in my rice cooker. An old style Zoji.
The rice smelled like brown rice as it cooked,  It didn't have the nice scent of Basmati at all.
When it was done, the rice had stuck to the bottom of the rice pot. Something that rarely happens here.
The rice tasted like cardboard. Not even a hint of basmati flavor that I could discern.
Even my husband commented that the rice tasted odd.
oh well.  This product is off my list. We have bought plain old Kroger brand brown rice that tasted better than this.
summary: Tastes Better Than It Did Yesterday.

This is a low sodium broth that tastes as good as a mass-manufactured low-sodium broth can taste--- even though it lacks the savory richness that homemade broth can offer. The packaging allows the flavor to avoid becoming victim to the metallic taste that canning can cause. More useful for making soups and as a recipe ingredient rather than drinking straight up, although there is nothing wrong with doing that either. 140mg of sodium per serving and 4 servings per 32 oz container, according to the packaging. For people watching their sodium intake: "Low sodium" (<140 mg) is different from "Very Low Sodium" (<35 mg) and "Sodium Free" (<5 mg).

reviewText: I haven't had my GladWare containers long enough to comment on the cracking or tearing of the lids yet.  I do however despise the fact that the big knob sticking out of the lid for the "interlocking lid" feature make stacking these containers VERY difficult.  I cook on weekends and freeze food for consumption during the week.  I often do chili, beef & noodles, and other soups.  I used to do this with the Ziploc Snap & Seal containers and they worked perfectly.  I could stack up a dozen of the 4x4x4" containers and carefully walk them to the garage, set them down and start adding them to the freezer.  The bottoms stacked flat onto the lid below them and they were overall sturdy enough to stand on their own.  Then I had to toss all of them into recycling after a house fire.  Now you can't find the Snap & Seal product unless you're willing to pay a crazy amount for the remainder of someone's stock.  I bought GladWare instead.  Unfortunately these containers do not stack worth a crap on top of another container.  At least not until the contents are frozen solid.  I stacked these 3 high full of chili the other day and I had to be extremely careful not to bump the stack or they'd fall over.  I miss my Ziploc Snal & Seal!
summary: Stacking with these things creates the Leaning Tower of GladWare!  You have been warned

reviewText: The taste is decent, although I prefer hot jasmine green tea. Jasmine green tea normally smells nice, but you do not get that benefit if it is cold and inside of a plastic bottle. I would not buy this again.

Really really faint taste.  I think if I drank this blindfolded I might think it was water.

Ito En Tea Beverage, Unsweetened Oi Ocha Dark Green, 16.9 Ounce (500mL) (Pack of 12), by SopSai.
This is a product review only, and not an endorsement of the vendor. There may be less expensive vendors available on Amazon, and it may be even less expensive than that in the supermarkets.

This very good unsweetened dark green tea has a heavy taste, and it would benefit from adding some ice water or ice to it in a glass to thin it out a bit, like some bottled black teas. The heavy concentration of tea also adds to its acidity. It does have a bit of a grassy taste, common in many green teas, but especially so in dark green teas. There is also a bit of Matcha  tea powder grittiness, which takes away the smoothness of the green tea.  Processed foods in general contain far too much sugar and salt, but this product does not contain any sugar, making it a healthier beverage to drink.
This dark green tea is an acquired taste. It contains powdered tea leaf residue, similar to Matcha tea, and has a slightly gritty mouth feel to it due to the presence of the leaf residue. It also contains 30mg of Sodium (salt) per serving, or 60mg of salt for the whole bottle, something that does not improve the taste of any tea. I am not sure if the salt is added as a preservative, but if it is, it should be reduced to 10mg or even 5mg, the way bottled teas used to be sold.

On the plus side, it does not contain any sweeteners, food coloring, or flavoring. The only additives are Sodium and Ascorbic Acid (Vitamin C). Matcha tea lovers will probably give this tea a higher rating, but overall, this is not quite my cup of tea, and I can only give it three Amazon stars.

Prime Pantry is something of a godsend when you haven't time to go to the store yourself.  So then the question becomes, are its prices and offerings of comparable value?  Answer for most common things, is 'yes'.  So here, you have essentially two TUNA choices, Bumble Bee or Chicken of the Sea.  So I got both.  And of the two, you have chunk light, and albacore, the latter allgedly being better and more expensive.  So I got both.

NO DIFFERENCE between them that I can taste.  NO DIFFERENCE between the two albacores, that I can see.  Scant difference in calories per 2 oz serving, with Chicken of the Sea a tad lower.

So the only difference, is price.  I see no justification for the Bumble Bee 'gold', which is about 20% higher in price, versus Bumble Bee albacore regular, which is of the same price as Chicken of the Sea albacore.  They all look and taste the same.  Surprisingly, there's no difference in taste (but a difference in looks) with the chunk light tuna.  But no difference, between the brands or within the brands.  The 12 oz is a better buy in price.

They are all tasteless canned tuna.  Fresh tuna tastes like heaven.  So canned tuna is what you use to get protein, for a sandwich (mackerel is far better, even for that or just on its own).  Duke's Mayo is far superior (more eggy), compared to the more popular brands, and is not sold in Prime Pantry, pity.  That's the only way I know of to drown out the dry blah canned tuna taste.  Or, mix in a tsp of Hoosier Hill's cheese powder (any flavor).

In short, canned tuna is bleh.  All tasting the same so get the cheapest, unless you're making a salad others will see, in which case spring for the albacore.

reviewText: Carcinogenic

Caveat emptor!  I was not paying enough attention to the ingredients when I purchased a case of this almond milk.  The taste and texture is fine as the intended use is for mixing with protein powders (mainly Sequel Naturals Vega line).  The difference I notice is that the Pacific Foods almond "beverage" thickens with the protein powder much more noticeably than the refrigerated-case grocery store almond milks I've tried.  I don't know if it's the carrageenan or some other component in this product, maybe the rice starch.  I add additional water so the protein shake will pour.  The other type I usually use contains guar gum but no carageenan.  Nothing wrong with the product, just my personal opinion.  Price point is very good when buying the whole case.  I would consider purchasing this again if the carrageenen-free version of almond milk was unavailable.

This review is from: Wheaties Cereal, 15.6-Ounce Boxes (Pack of 14) (Grocery)
Wheaties Cereal, 15.6-Ounce (442g) Boxes (Pack of 14), from General Mills Cereals.
This rather plain wheat cereal is another timeless classic. It has added vitamins, but even after eating two bowls of it, it still does not equal the vitamin content of one daily vitamin pill. It stands up to milk quite well before eventually becoming soggy. It is medium high (180mg) in Sodium (salt), and low in sugar (4g). Unfortunately, it is not tasty enough to interest me in having a second helping of it. I give this good, but rather plain, breakfast cereal consisting of wheat flakes, -three Amazon stars.

The Nutrition Facts, and Ingredients, as listed on the box:

Nutrition Facts:
Serving Size  cup (27g); Servings Per Container about 16.
Amount Per Serving:
Calories 100 (Calories from Fat 5).
Total Fat 0.5g (Saturated Fat 0g, Trans Fat 0g, Polyunsaturated Fat 0g, Monounsaturated Fat 0g).

reviewText: I like Chex, especially cinnamon flavored or in the party mix.  I thought I'd try vanilla.  Big mistake.  It only has 8 grams of sugar per serving, much lower than many other sugary cereals.  My recent favorite, Raisin Bran Crunch, has 19 grams.  So really, why does Chex Vanilla taste so sweet?  It's overpoweringly sweet.  I don't even notice the vanilla over all that sweetness.  I get sick thinking about it.  If you like sweet, this might be your thing.  I like sweet, but not this much.

I was thrilled to learn that General Mills began offering gluten-free rice chex and corn Chex a while back.  And being a chocolate lover, when they also made Chocolate Chex gluten-free, I could not wait to try it.  It was quite a disappointment.  To me at least, the chocolate flavor seemed to be just that - flavor - not what actually tastes like real chocolate.  It's not awful, and I won't have a problem eating the whole case of 6 boxes, but it'll be just a bit at a time until all the boxes are gone.  I don't anticipate purchasing more of it.  I truly wanted this to be a 5-star product - it just isn't.
Bought for my rats.  They didn't like it, I guess they are picky

This is not a great cereal, but it's not horrible either. The texture is good and not as dry or crumbly as other fiber cereals. There's a nice, satisfying crunch to this. However, the flakes have a maple taste to them that is not all to my liking. It initially tastes OK, but the aftertaste is somewhat unpleasant -- sort of an earthly flavor tinged with maple.  The clusters of oats are the best part of the cereal, but they are few and far between -- it's mostly flakes.

I'll certainly finish the box, but I would not get this again.

reviewText: Bag not as big as I thought and not has much rice because bag is only half full.

If you are one of those people who think that all rice tastes the same, then maybe this review won't strike a cord. But I love different rices, and enjoy them with different meals.

Jasmine rice has a floral smell and taste. And it's not sticky, like other long-grain rices. It's great with middle eastern meals, like falafels or shwarma. I saut garlic, butter and bit of saffron and mix it with the cooked rice. It's delicious.

Unfortunately, this brand seems to be less inspiring. It has the mouth feel of good jasmine rice. But it doesn't have the taste. It's a little bland, not unlike the boxed rices you get from a certain American rice company. For the price, I should have gotten a better tasting rice, but this wasn't it.

I'm disappointed.

Worse yet, the rice arrived with a tear in the packaging, so about a half of the rice ended up in the Amazon box. Amazon replaced it, and my star rating has nothing to do with this issue, but it is frustrating.

It was fairly expensive when compared to local markets. Even when rinsing it did not cook well in a microwave steamer. To be fair it was the only brand to date to be used in that steamer so it might be the process not the product. If this is your first experience with jasmine rice it might be worth the small size for the cost. If this is to become a new favorite I would look to local suppliers in larger bags.
This Jasmine rice is not as fragrant as other brands. If you like Jasmine rice for the great taste then this rice shouldn't be top pick.

I had some delicious pumpkin cereal that I bought at a gourmet market last fall. Since it was a seasonal item, they no longer have it. Hoping this was similar, I took a chance. It is not pumpkin-y at all. I guess the "pumpkin" comes from adding pumpkin seeds to tasteless raisin bran. This cereal also has a lot of calories, about 220 per serving. That's pretty high compared to tasteless raisin bran. Now I have 6 boxes of this stuff. What to do?

I was very surprised by how tough and chewy these raisins are, right from the very first bowl. I had to take a good second look at the carton to make sure I was eating from the right box and not the Kellog's Raisin Bran I had opened a few weeks ago. I don't remember ever remarking on the consistency of the raisins in my cereal before, so this was a first. The only times I've had raisins this chewy were when they'd been sitting out for a while and gone stale. This box was freshly opened, so freshness was not the problem. Without exaggeration, the raisins are almost as dense and tough as pencil erasers. (I squeezed both with my fingers to compare.) The flakes are good and satisfyingly crunchy, but the raisins will give your jaws a good workout. As for the health benefits of this cereal, I have no doubts. Health professionals recommend getting 25-35g of fiber a day for an average adult, so the 11g per serving in here goes a long way towards the total (28%). Unlike some of the other reviewers, I did not detect any fishy smell or odd taste. I am used to eating healthy foods (some of which are truly dreadful!) and have no complaints about this product other than the raisins. I love Nature's Path cereal. Just not this one. I recommend Nature's Path Organic Flax Plus Maple Pecan Crunch Cereal instead. Much better tasting and no rubbery raisins.
summary: Nice crunchy cereal, but raisins are tough and chewy

1 bag = 204 calories

The easy way to find out how many calories there are in what you are eating is to know how many calories are in the entire bag, box, can, etc. since people rarely eat "one serving".  And the number of servings and the number of calories per servings is always included in the nutritional information on the container.  However I have noticed on Amazon that this is not the case.  When the nutritional information is shown it's "ONE" serving, in this case 18 grams.  How unhelpful is that?  They make it a process to find out how many calories are in this bag of mangoes, for example.  They tell you how many calories are in 18 grams; I personally think it's an attempt at deception or misleading if you want to be kind by the vendor.  In any case, there are 204 calories in one bag.  one ounce = 28.349 grams; 2.2 ounces per bag X 28.349 = 62.368 grams; 62.368 grams/18 = 3.465 servings per bag.  3.465 X 59 calories per 18 grams = 204.428 calories.  I'm going to ask Amazon to ask the vendors that when they say they are including the information on the product in the description that they provide all of it and part of this is the number of servings contained.  I believe that the vendors are required by law to provide the number of servings on the container but I'm not sure about online.  This is conveniently left out; plus, who the heck deals with servings in grams?  When is the last time you measured out a serving in grams?  Americans use ounces.
summary: How many calories are in the bag?  How hard is that?

reviewText: not my favorite

We typically LOVE Nature's Path (Envirokidz) cereal because they are GLUTEN FREE and one of the only brands that claim to be GMO free & actually have tested to be TRUE to their word several times done by INDEPENDENT researchers.  While I don't want my kids eating cereal every day, I feel that at least this is a decent option for breakfast when needed in a hurry.

That said, this cereal has a meh taste.  It's basically the Gorilla Munch cereal with some cinnamon on it, but if the cereal sits in the milk, rice milk, etc. for more than a minute the flavoring comes off & it is very plain.  If you don't mind something plain with a mild cinnamon hint to it after adding it to milk, you'll probably like this.  But if you want your cereal to maintain the yummy flavor filled taste even when milk is added, like their Peanut Butter Panda Puffs (YUMMMMM!!!), you may be disappointed.  This started out at $2.75 a box via S&S but quickly went up to $4.25 a box the next month.  I am not ordering any more & cancelled my subscription.

I gave it 3 stars for being a great company with great products & coming out with a new flavor of cereal.  I took off 2 stars because the cereal lacks cinnamon flavor once milk is added... and since that is typically how cereal is eaten, with milk, I don't think taking away 2 stars is unreasonable, for the flavor basically disappearing when wet.  I will not buy it again.

reviewText:
These were my favorite flavor of Nut Thins, although the Pepper Jack flavor was a close second.  The cheddar flavoring is intense in these; they are quite delicious.  I once found them to be a healthy and relatively low-caloric snack.  I miss them.

I would give this product, and all Nut Thin flavors, a five-star rating because of the great taste but I cannot.  I know many of  you will be mad at me for rating this product as I have and will thereby consider my review unhelpful, but... so be it.  I have principles that I must remain true to.  Here is why I downgraded the rating from five to three stars:

When I buy a food product, I want to have confidence in the company which manufacturers that food.  Unfortunately, that is no longer the case with Blue Diamond's products.

It has recently come to my attention that Blue Diamond Growers (makes of Nut Thins) has joined in the campaign to stop GMO labeling, by supporting and contributing to Monsanto's and other mega-agricultural interests' efforts to prevent people, that is---you and me, from being given label-information that will inform us to what we are eating and help us make smart and healthy food choices.  Those of us who actually read labels, that is.

It's unfortunate that this company is not supporting GMO-labeling.  I would probably buy these crackers even if the label stated, "may contain GMOs," but I feel I have the right to know, as do you.  Health food and organic companies have included responsible labeling for a long time, and there is no reason why these other major food manufacturers shouldn't follow suit.  They change their packaging, including their labeling, all the time, so they cannot say it would be a heavy financial burden to do this.  Blue Diamond should support and respect the intelligence of its customer base.  It apparently doesn't.  By trying to quash efforts to pass laws requiring GMO-labeling, and in many cases, attempting to reverse the laws that some states have recently passed requiring GMO labeling, Blue Diamond is showing that it cares more about its own interests rather than the public's interest which it serves.

For that reason, solely for that reason, I cannot recommend these Nut Thins and will no longer be purchasing them.
summary: Will No Longer Buy These (Alas, because they are tasty!).

I love the idea of using natural, renewable and sustainable cleaning products in the household, but after using these a few times the results are somewhat disappointing when compared to Cascade Platinum. I first tried one tablet in a very lightly soiled dishwasher load with the "Heavy" setting and there were a few ceramic plates that did not come out "spotless", but clean enough to just rinse and wipe off. I then later tried 2 of the Ecover tablets in a more soiled Dishwasher load on the "Heavy" setting and had considerably more dishes that were still dirty. My other Cascade Platinum tablets (not just the "Complete", but the "Platinum" type, there IS a difference) seem to handle quite a bit more than these tablets do. Even though these tablets are a "Naturally Derived" product and are considerably cheaper, the use of water needed to clean the dishes with more than one cycle, or pre/post rinse negates any ecological and cost savings benefits, in my opinion. These might be great for simply washing cups or cereal bowls, perhaps lightly soiled silverware too, but I wouldn't use these to try and remove anything like melted cheese, microwaved sauce drops or anything of that nature.
summary: Meh. My other product is better.

reviewText: taste good
Not a family favorite, but still good juice.

This is a tasty tart beverage that is about 100 calories per cup and has 28g of sugar in a cup.  According to a nutrition site: "Ocean Spray Cranberry Juice Cocktail contains just four ingredients. Filtered water is the first and most plentiful ingredient listed on the product label, followed by cranberry juice concentrate -- the two combine to form the juice. Because cranberries are naturally quite tart, beet or cane sugar  appears third in the ingredient list as sweeteners. Ascorbic acid, or vitamin C, is the fourth and last ingredient."

If you have to watch your sugar intake - which many Americans do as we are told we eat too much sugar - this juice cocktail has added beet or cane sugar.  For myself, I prefer to drink other juices which don't have sugar added to them.  If sugar isn't an issue for you, this may be a four or five star beverage
summary: Tasty But Note the Added Sugar

As I get older, I am finding myself making more of an effort to eat a healthier, well-balanced diet, and incorporate as many organic ingredients into my daily routine as I can (as much as my wallet will allow!). On that quest in shopping Amazon Pantry, I came across Wolfgang Puck's Organic Chicken with Wild Rice soup. I thought to myself, it's Wolfgang Puck, so it's got to be delicious, right? Not exactly.

First off, I was disappointed when I got the shipment. The can was MUCH smaller than I expected. Think Campbell's small soup can. I figured for the price, it would be a bigger can. BUT, I will admit, this was entirely my fault, as I did not pay attention to the ounces in the can before ordering.

That being said, I popped open the can to prepare lunch, expecting at least a FEW pieces of chicken and vegetables mixed in with the broth and rice. Not so. I would guestimate at least 80% of the soup is broth and rice. I counted 2 small chicken chunks. After trying it, the flavor was lack-luster. I can't even describe it, it was just very bland. Also, VERY high in sodium! (over 800mg) - Very disappointed, I definitely will not be purchasing this again.
summary: Just an "ok" soup... but very little in the bowl!

reviewText: a very average mix but its ok.

I like the actual wrap itself, but am giving this a less-than-flattering rating because the delivery system is outright poor.

The cling wrap itself is good stuff...it's strong, very stretchy, really clings to dishes, has good heat resistance, and the price for 200 square feet is very reasonable.

However, the system in which you must use to unwind & cut this wrap makes the usage of Glad's wrap more difficult than others I have used. The placement of the cutting blade is awkward...you have to hold the entire thing on a very awkward angle to physically see what you are doing. Further (as others have noted), you really need to pull HARD at a strong upward angle to get it to cut...doing this sometimes results in the piece you are cutting stretching, and then  wrinkling up as it snaps back after being cut, which can render the piece you just cut useless unless you want to attempt to untangle what just happened. Finally, the design sometimes results in the roll itself accumulating a small amount of wrap on the outer edge of the roll, eventually resulting in you needing to remove the roll from the box, and remove this accumulation. The cutting system is probably like this for safety purposes, but I find it makes using Cling Wrap much more frustrating than other products I have used.

With this kind of product that you frequently interact with, the delivery system is just as important as the product given you are interacting with it all of the time, and this is the make or break of convenience. I like Glad's wrap more than the Kirkland wrap I use, but the Kirkland has a much easier delivery system. As I use clear wrap like 3+ times a day, the additional time & effort to use Glad's Cling Wrap over others adds up...and so as much as I like the wrap, this is not a product I will be purchasing in the future. Glad is making a great quality wrap, but I hope that in the near future they change the packaging.
summary: Great quality wrap...terrible delivery system - compared to others brands, usage is more difficult/frustrating

reviewText:
An interesting concept on the traditional plastic wrap, which in general, works well. Hubby thinks this stuff is "fun" - so who am I to complain when he decides he wants to help pack up lunches or store leftovers?!
The wrap can be a bit of a hassle if it sticks to itself when you are getting it off the roll - it takes a bit of getting used to the one side being very sticky and having a real liking for the corners to stick to themselves.
However, this stickiness is great for keeping the wrap tightly over bowls or plates or any containers that you want to have a nice tight seal on - it really does work well.
I wasn't too sure about this product when I bought it, but I must say I do like it, and once you get the hang of getting out your piece without it catching onto itself, it is a very handy and versatile plastic cling wrap.
EDIT:
After using this wrap for longer I have noticed that it leaves behind a sticky residue, especially the longer the wrap is left over something, the more pressure that's used, or if the item with wrap is microwaved, (even though the box says the wrap is microwave safe). This discovery is a disappointment and as a result I probably wouldn't buy again.
summary: Unique, versatile wrap that really sticks (see Edit)

Life Cereal, Cinnamon, 18 Oz (513g), by Life Cereal.
Life Cereal, Cinnamon, is a good cereal, with a sugary taste and very little cinnamon. Unfortunately, they have it backwards.  It would be better with more cinnamon and less sugar.  In terms of nutrition, the vitamin content is minimal, except for the Folic Acid content of 100% MDR (minimum daily requirement).  The sodium content of 150mg is about average, and the sugar content is above average at 8g, compared to Rice Krispies 190mg Sodium (salt) and 4mg sugar, and Cheerios 140mg salt and 1g sugar.  For anyone on a low sugar or low salt diet, Life Cereal, Cinnamon, is not your best choice.  The Nutrition Facts and Ingredients, as listed on the box, are as follows:

Nutrition Facts: Serving Size  cup (32g), Servings Per Container about 16.
Amount Per Serving:
Calories 120  (Calories from Fat 15).
Total Fat  1.5g (Saturated Fat 0g, Trans Fat 0g,  Polyunsaturated Fat 0.5g, Monounsaturated Fat 0.5g).
Cholesterol  0mg.
Sodium  150mg.
Potassium  85mg.
Total Carbohydrate  25g ((Dietary Fiber 2g (Soluble Fiber <1g), Sugars 8g, Other Carbohydrate 15g)).
Protein  3g.

Ingredients: Whole grain oat flour, sugar, corn flour, whole wheat flour, rice flour, calcium carbonate, salt, cinnamon, disodium phosphate, caramel color, reduced iron, niacinamide, dextrin, zinc oxide, yellow 6, BHT (a preservative), yellow 5, thiamin mononitrate, red 40, natural flavor, riboflavin, pyridoxine hydrochloride, folic acid, blue 1.

CONTAINS WHEAT INGREDIENTS.
18 GRAMS WHOLE GRAINS. 100% WHOLE GRAIN, 20g or more per serving, EAT 48g OR MORE OF WHOLE GRAINS DAILY (WholeGrainsCouncil.org). (Note: The front of the box says it contains 18g per serving!).

reviewText: There seems to be some misrepresentation of this product (not by Amazon, but by the manufacturer). We purchased this thinking it was sweetened with a stevia derivative, however that is not the case; the sweetener used is erythritol, a sugar alcohol derived from a yeast moniliella. Although it has been approved by the FDA and is used extensively, it is only 50-60% as sweet as sugar. It is just ok as far as the taste goes.

It's OK for being 0 calories... stevia is definitely not as good as real sugar would be so don't expect that kind of sweetness.

Personally I would not buy it again unless it's at a deep discount, but it's great that it's all natural.

I was very surprised by how tough and chewy these raisins are, right from the very first bowl. I had to take a good second look at the carton to make sure I was eating from the right box and not the Kellog's Raisin Bran I had opened a few weeks ago. I don't remember ever remarking on the consistency of the raisins in my cereal before, so this was a first. The only times I've had raisins this chewy were when they'd been sitting out for a while and gone stale. This box was freshly opened, so freshness was not the problem. Without exaggeration, the raisins are almost as dense and tough as pencil erasers. (I squeezed both with my fingers to compare.) The flakes are good and satisfyingly crunchy, but the raisins will give your jaws a good workout. As for the health benefits of this cereal, I have no doubts. Health professionals recommend getting 25-35g of fiber a day for an average adult, so the 11g per serving in here goes a long way towards the total (28%). Unlike some of the other reviewers, I did not detect any fishy smell or odd taste. I am used to eating healthy foods (some of which are truly dreadful!) and have no complaints about this product other than the raisins. I love Nature's Path cereal. Just not this one. I recommend Nature's Path Organic Flax Plus Maple Pecan Crunch Cereal instead. Much better tasting and no rubbery raisins.
summary: Nice crunchy cereal, but raisins are tough and chewy

1 bag = 204 calories

The easy way to find out how many calories there are in what you are eating is to know how many calories are in the entire bag, box, can, etc. since people rarely eat "one serving".  And the number of servings and the number of calories per servings is always included in the nutritional information on the container.  However I have noticed on Amazon that this is not the case.  When the nutritional information is shown it's "ONE" serving, in this case 18 grams.  How unhelpful is that?  They make it a process to find out how many calories are in this bag of mangoes, for example.  They tell you how many calories are in 18 grams; I personally think it's an attempt at deception or misleading if you want to be kind by the vendor.  In any case, there are 204 calories in one bag.  one ounce = 28.349 grams; 2.2 ounces per bag X 28.349 = 62.368 grams; 62.368 grams/18 = 3.465 servings per bag.  3.465 X 59 calories per 18 grams = 204.428 calories.  I'm going to ask Amazon to ask the vendors that when they say they are including the information on the product in the description that they provide all of it and part of this is the number of servings contained.  I believe that the vendors are required by law to provide the number of servings on the container but I'm not sure about online.  This is conveniently left out; plus, who the heck deals with servings in grams?  When is the last time you measured out a serving in grams?  Americans use ounces.
summary: How many calories are in the bag?  How hard is that?

We typically LOVE Nature's Path (Envirokidz) cereal because they are GLUTEN FREE and one of the only brands that claim to be GMO free & actually have tested to be TRUE to their word several times done by INDEPENDENT researchers.  While I don't want my kids eating cereal every day, I feel that at least this is a decent option for breakfast when needed in a hurry.

That said, this cereal has a meh taste.  It's basically the Gorilla Munch cereal with some cinnamon on it, but if the cereal sits in the milk, rice milk, etc. for more than a minute the flavoring comes off & it is very plain.  If you don't mind something plain with a mild cinnamon hint to it after adding it to milk, you'll probably like this.  But if you want your cereal to maintain the yummy flavor filled taste even when milk is added, like their Peanut Butter Panda Puffs (YUMMMMM!!!), you may be disappointed.  This started out at $2.75 a box via S&S but quickly went up to $4.25 a box the next month.  I am not ordering any more & cancelled my subscription.

I gave it 3 stars for being a great company with great products & coming out with a new flavor of cereal.  I took off 2 stars because the cereal lacks cinnamon flavor once milk is added... and since that is typically how cereal is eaten, with milk, I don't think taking away 2 stars is unreasonable, for the flavor basically disappearing when wet.  I will not buy it again.

reviewText:
These were my favorite flavor of Nut Thins, although the Pepper Jack flavor was a close second.  The cheddar flavoring is intense in these; they are quite delicious.  I once found them to be a healthy and relatively low-caloric snack.  I miss them.

I would give this product, and all Nut Thin flavors, a five-star rating because of the great taste but I cannot.  I know many of  you will be mad at me for rating this product as I have and will thereby consider my review unhelpful, but... so be it.  I have principles that I must remain true to.  Here is why I downgraded the rating from five to three stars:

When I buy a food product, I want to have confidence in the company which manufacturers that food.  Unfortunately, that is no longer the case with Blue Diamond's products.

It has recently come to my attention that Blue Diamond Growers (makes of Nut Thins) has joined in the campaign to stop GMO labeling, by supporting and contributing to Monsanto's and other mega-agricultural interests' efforts to prevent people, that is---you and me, from being given label-information that will inform us to what we are eating and help us make smart and healthy food choices.  Those of us who actually read labels, that is.

It's unfortunate that this company is not supporting GMO-labeling.  I would probably buy these crackers even if the label stated, "may contain GMOs," but I feel I have the right to know, as do you.  Health food and organic companies have included responsible labeling for a long time, and there is no reason why these other major food manufacturers shouldn't follow suit.  They change their packaging, including their labeling, all the time, so they cannot say it would be a heavy financial burden to do this.  Blue Diamond should support and respect the intelligence of its customer base.  It apparently doesn't.  By trying to quash efforts to pass laws requiring GMO-labeling, and in many cases, attempting to reverse the laws that some states have recently passed requiring GMO labeling, Blue Diamond is showing that it cares more about its own interests rather than the public's interest which it serves.

For that reason, solely for that reason, I cannot recommend these Nut Thins and will no longer be purchasing them.
summary: Will No Longer Buy These (Alas, because they are tasty!).

I love the idea of using natural, renewable and sustainable cleaning products in the household, but after using these a few times the results are somewhat disappointing when compared to Cascade Platinum. I first tried one tablet in a very lightly soiled dishwasher load with the "Heavy" setting and there were a few ceramic plates that did not come out "spotless", but clean enough to just rinse and wipe off. I then later tried 2 of the Ecover tablets in a more soiled Dishwasher load on the "Heavy" setting and had considerably more dishes that were still dirty. My other Cascade Platinum tablets (not just the "Complete", but the "Platinum" type, there IS a difference) seem to handle quite a bit more than these tablets do. Even though these tablets are a "Naturally Derived" product and are considerably cheaper, the use of water needed to clean the dishes with more than one cycle, or pre/post rinse negates any ecological and cost savings benefits, in my opinion. These might be great for simply washing cups or cereal bowls, perhaps lightly soiled silverware too, but I wouldn't use these to try and remove anything like melted cheese, microwaved sauce drops or anything of that nature.
summary: Meh. My other product is better.

Not a family favorite, but still good juice.

This is a tasty tart beverage that is about 100 calories per cup and has 28g of sugar in a cup.  According to a nutrition site: "Ocean Spray Cranberry Juice Cocktail contains just four ingredients. Filtered water is the first and most plentiful ingredient listed on the product label, followed by cranberry juice concentrate -- the two combine to form the juice. Because cranberries are naturally quite tart, beet or cane sugar  appears third in the ingredient list as sweeteners. Ascorbic acid, or vitamin C, is the fourth and last ingredient."

If you have to watch your sugar intake - which many Americans do as we are told we eat too much sugar - this juice cocktail has added beet or cane sugar.  For myself, I prefer to drink other juices which don't have sugar added to them.  If sugar isn't an issue for you, this may be a four or five star beverage
summary: Tasty But Note the Added Sugar

As I get older, I am finding myself making more of an effort to eat a healthier, well-balanced diet, and incorporate as many organic ingredients into my daily routine as I can (as much as my wallet will allow!). On that quest in shopping Amazon Pantry, I came across Wolfgang Puck's Organic Chicken with Wild Rice soup. I thought to myself, it's Wolfgang Puck, so it's got to be delicious, right? Not exactly.

First off, I was disappointed when I got the shipment. The can was MUCH smaller than I expected. Think Campbell's small soup can. I figured for the price, it would be a bigger can. BUT, I will admit, this was entirely my fault, as I did not pay attention to the ounces in the can before ordering.

That being said, I popped open the can to prepare lunch, expecting at least a FEW pieces of chicken and vegetables mixed in with the broth and rice. Not so. I would guestimate at least 80% of the soup is broth and rice. I counted 2 small chicken chunks. After trying it, the flavor was lack-luster. I can't even describe it, it was just very bland. Also, VERY high in sodium! (over 800mg) - Very disappointed, I definitely will not be purchasing this again.

reviewText: a very average mix but its ok.

I like the actual wrap itself, but am giving this a less-than-flattering rating because the delivery system is outright poor.

The cling wrap itself is good stuff...it's strong, very stretchy, really clings to dishes, has good heat resistance, and the price for 200 square feet is very reasonable.

However, the system in which you must use to unwind & cut this wrap makes the usage of Glad's wrap more difficult than others I have used. The placement of the cutting blade is awkward...you have to hold the entire thing on a very awkward angle to physically see what you are doing. Further (as others have noted), you really need to pull HARD at a strong upward angle to get it to cut...doing this sometimes results in the piece you are cutting stretching, and then  wrinkling up as it snaps back after being cut, which can render the piece you just cut useless unless you want to attempt to untangle what just happened. Finally, the design sometimes results in the roll itself accumulating a small amount of wrap on the outer edge of the roll, eventually resulting in you needing to remove the roll from the box, and remove this accumulation. The cutting system is probably like this for safety purposes, but I find it makes using Cling Wrap much more frustrating than other products I have used.

With this kind of product that you frequently interact with, the delivery system is just as important as the product given you are interacting with it all of the time, and this is the make or break of convenience. I like Glad's wrap more than the Kirkland wrap I use, but the Kirkland has a much easier delivery system. As I use clear wrap like 3+ times a day, the additional time & effort to use Glad's Cling Wrap over others adds up...and so as much as I like the wrap, this is not a product I will be purchasing in the future. Glad is making a great quality wrap, but I hope that in the near future they change the packaging.
summary: Great quality wrap...terrible delivery system - compared to others brands, usage is more difficult/frustrating

reviewText:
An interesting concept on the traditional plastic wrap, which in general, works well. Hubby thinks this stuff is "fun" - so who am I to complain when he decides he wants to help pack up lunches or store leftovers?!
The wrap can be a bit of a hassle if it sticks to itself when you are getting it off the roll - it takes a bit of getting used to the one side being very sticky and having a real liking for the corners to stick to themselves.
However, this stickiness is great for keeping the wrap tightly over bowls or plates or any containers that you want to have a nice tight seal on - it really does work well.
I wasn't too sure about this product when I bought it, but I must say I do like it, and once you get the hang of getting out your piece without it catching onto itself, it is a very handy and versatile plastic cling wrap.
EDIT:
After using this wrap for longer I have noticed that it leaves behind a sticky residue, especially the longer the wrap is left over something, the more pressure that's used, or if the item with wrap is microwaved, (even though the box says the wrap is microwave safe). This discovery is a disappointment and as a result I probably wouldn't buy again.
summary: Unique, versatile wrap that really sticks (see Edit)

Life Cereal, Cinnamon, 18 Oz (513g), by Life Cereal.
Life Cereal, Cinnamon, is a good cereal, with a sugary taste and very little cinnamon. Unfortunately, they have it backwards.  It would be better with more cinnamon and less sugar.  In terms of nutrition, the vitamin content is minimal, except for the Folic Acid content of 100% MDR (minimum daily requirement).  The sodium content of 150mg is about average, and the sugar content is above average at 8g, compared to Rice Krispies 190mg Sodium (salt) and 4mg sugar, and Cheerios 140mg salt and 1g sugar.  For anyone on a low sugar or low salt diet, Life Cereal, Cinnamon, is not your best choice.  The Nutrition Facts and Ingredients, as listed on the box, are as follows:

reviewText: There seems to be some misrepresentation of this product (not by Amazon, but by the manufacturer). We purchased this thinking it was sweetened with a stevia derivative, however that is not the case; the sweetener used is erythritol, a sugar alcohol derived from a yeast moniliella. Although it has been approved by the FDA and is used extensively, it is only 50-60% as sweet as sugar. It is just ok as far as the taste goes.

It's OK for being 0 calories... stevia is definitely not as good as real sugar would be so don't expect that kind of sweetness.

Personally I would not buy it again unless it's at a deep discount, but it's great that it's all natural.
summary: It's OK.... not terrible but not great either,

Thank you

reviewText:
This pink lemonade flavor is very mild until you get about 4 "squirts" (it dispenses in a stream, not drop-by-drop) in a bottle of water. At that point the lemonade flavor is definitely pronounced, but I found it had a very chemical taste. Not sure if this particular flavor is the problem.

So, if you are the type that likes to drink water with just a hint of flavor, then this will probably be fine for you. If you like a more robust flavor (the picture below shows how dark the water gets if you add about 4 squirts), then you might be turned off by the artificial taste.

reviewText:
I really don't like these. Unfortunately the "dri-weave" cover tends to fall apart through the day. It rips open and the silica which absorbs menstrual blood is exposed to the skin. Silica is not only poisonous but it also can cause chemical burns on sensitive skin. It's very common in disposable diapers if the silica crystals touch a baby's bottom, to cause a chemical burn on the baby. Many pads are made of similar materials as disposable diapers.

Other than the ripping, these are good pads and I have no experienced leaks with these. To keep them from ripping I change them often, especially if I see the dri-weave cover becoming weak, even if the pad is not ready to be changed. They do bunch up a lot and the wings come detached sometimes. So these would not be good for an active person who moves around a lot. Maybe if you are just going to be sitting around these are okay.

didnt notice a difference just made my teeth hurt >.>
Mom asked me to get Crest 3D White Luxe strips for her.  While they were easy to use, she did not notice any improvement in tooth color.

It made my teeth hurt so badly that I just wanted to rip my teeth out by the end of the first week. I tried using sensitive tooth paste like someone had suggested, but after a few hours my teeth hurt again it was unbearable. I tried it again a couple weeks later and just doing it once killed me. I could tell a difference on my teeth and how they were becoming whiter, but it hurts so bad that I couldn't finish.
These whitestrips worked so-so for me.  I think I've had better experience with these in the past.  Maybe, these are not as strong/intense as other Crest ones I have tried in the past.

I haven't found any OTC product that works better, but these aren't magical like they claim to be, I don't see a huge difference.  However, I do see a difference, so that's why I'm buying them for the fourth time.

I am at least halfway through all the whitening strips and, frankly, I don't see that much improvement.  I would say that my teeth have whitened MAYBE 1 to 3 shades, no more.  The box makes the claim that it gets rid of 14 years of stain.  I don't think so.  This item isn't worth the money I spent on it.  i'll be looking for something else.

I drink a lot of coffee and over the years I realize now why vehicles slow down when I smile, they think the light is turning yellow!  These strips do work, somewhat.  It takes time and patience, and once you get them on you have to be careful removing them, because if you have a loose tooth these will remove it, they really stick.

You may want to dry you teeth before applying them otherwise they slip around and get wet, fold over and stick to themselves and instead of white teeth you'll have a red face, as it's frustrating to waste these.  The can get expensive.

You may also get uneven results, with white spots on some teeth where the strip worked better on a high spot.  The 3D?  Not sure, unless it has something to do with the way you have to use a mirror and both hands to peel and apply them and avoid the roof of your mouth, which I doubt you'll want to whiten.

So, overall?  If it's that important to you, don't expect to be blinding people with your renewed glimmer.  Oh, and yes you do have to keep buying them as the change in shade is tempoary.

If you have little critters in your house, make sure to always store your bottle in the fridge and never leave it out...not even accidentally for a few minutes.

reviewText:
The best part of waking up is...oh, wait, wrong jingle. Anyway, I am not a huge coffee fan. When I drink it, it is mostly because I need some caffeine. Brand isn't all that important to me, and I bought this because it was affordable rather than Maxwell House being some brand I actively seek out. It is fine for what it is. I have had coffee from whole beans freshly ground, different varieties, etc. Are some better than this? Sure. Does this work? Yeah...it does. The bigger thing for me is that the price was right. It is not overly bitter, it brews quickly enough, and I have enough to last me months considering how little I use in a given week.

If you need some specialty free trade coffee that was chewed on by the eastern diamondback rattler who carried it to a Moroccan tree goat who then trampled it while hand pressing it in a village that is supported for a year due to your one purchase then this probably isn't for you. If you just want some coffee, then this works.
summary: Just your standard fare of coffee.

Cake mix ingredients don't vary too much from flavor to flavor, but for some reason this mix ends up tasting like corn muffins to me instead of cake.

I do a lot of baking from scratch, but I commonly use these easy, inexpensive mixes to make cupcakes for the kids.  Some cupcakes we finish with frosting and others we leave plain. White cake mix and chocolate cake mix make lovely, yummy, plain cupcakes---but the yellow mix has the texture and flavor of a corn muffin.  I find that if I undercook the cupcakes slightly, the corn taste is a little less prevalent; if they are are baked to done-ness, the corn flavor seems to "blossom."

reviewText:
I used to be a Viva super enthusiast -- it was the only brand I'd use. But I had to look for a new brand after the Viva towels seemed to get worse and worse about shedding lint...like A LOT of lint. I can't do mirrors or glass with them anymore because I have to go back over them with a microfiber cloth to remove all the lint, no thanks. What did they change and why did they do it? I do have these in the garage still since they are good for spills, but I can no longer use them for everything like I used to.  I don't know what changed about the production or something, but the Viva towels all shed terribly now and are useless on reflective surfaces.

I now use Bounty Dura towels and are hooked on those!
summary: Used to be great, now they shed lint EVERYWHERE. Still good on spills.

Hunt's is what I would call a good "starter" for some tomato dishes, but it's not a sauce I could ever eat as-is. All the varieties (Meat, Traditional, Four Cheese, Garlic and Herb) are bland, with not much variation between them. Consistency of this sauce is pretty thin, with no visible chunks of anything---perfect for toddlers, less delicious for adults. I keep a few cans of Hunt's on hand, for last-minute dishes when i don't have time to simmer sauce for hours.

For pasta, I add more spices and garlic, sugar, sometimes mushroom/onion/peppers, and tomato paste to thicken. If I'm using this sauce as just part of a more complex dish, then the other flavors in the recipe usually serve to perk it up. Hunt's is a basic, inexpensive pantry staple for me, saves time and effort but can't really stand alone.

reviewText: I am overwhelmed by the number of five star reviews and believe me I tried to think of ways to give this product more than three stars. Well I tried that and sorry Campbells, I cannot for the life if myself go beyond the three stars. The meat balls need a vast amount of improvement and perhaps starting with  more meat would be in order. The spaghetti is just spaghetti and in this can soft and mushy. I like mine just like to came from being cooked and that is one reason I never eat left over spaghetti at my house. The sauce is just sauce with nothing I would say was great. You have  a product that is available for immediate warming and serving and a lot of people like that.

When I was a kid (a long time ago!), my mother would use Saran Wrap to wrap up left overs and cover plates and so on. Live and learn.

Now? I use it as well. It is wonderful for storing leftovers. It is useful for covering ingredients for my meals (mise en place?) to keep them fresh. It seemed to work well for my mother; it surely works well for me.

After all of these years. . . .  A satisfied customer!

Another good thing is the long shelf life. It seems like the dates on tuna cans are always later than other canned goods like vegetables or soups.

If you really like tuna, the American one is a nice splurge once in a while, but this is an ok everyday tuna for casseroles and tuna melts.

These are the traditional oats you've loved all your life. They take a little while to cook (5 minutes, not instant), but are worth the wait. They have the great nutrition you expect from oatmeal. If you like them sweetened, I recommend putting the sweetener in the water (with the salt, if desired) before adding the oats. Brown sugar is the bomb this way. You'll want to transfer them into a suitable container as you open each 4-pound bag, since the bags don't pour or seal very well. There are 2 bags in the box. These must be packaged for food service, as it says "not for retail sale" on the box. The ones I got are best if used by about 18 months from receipt and actually should be good for 8-12 months after that. If you can use 8 lbs in about 2 years, this is an economical way to buy your oatmeal. Recommended. Review of: Quaker Oats Old Fashioned Oatmeal, Breakfast Cereal, 128 Ounces

My son bought a package of the Jalapeno Potato Chips a couple weeks ago, and he and I have become addicted.

First, Kettle chips appear to be somewhat better in terms of fats etc. than many other chips, as one peruses the dietary information.

Second, individual chips are nice and crisp and have a good crunch value as you munch away at them.

Third, the jalapeno has some kick (not overly hot, of course). Too many products labelled as spicy are not, have no kick, and are as bland as can be. Here, you do get a slow noticeable burn from the jalapeno. My preference? A bit more heat. But I understand that most consumers would prefer somewhat less than I would. Still, decent spicyness.

All in all, I have been pretty happy with this product, in the few weeks since we first bought it. I now purchase a package each week in my foray to the local grocery store. . . .

reviewText: This toothpaste has a fresh taste. It's not exactly what I expected but does leave my breath fresh. It cleans my teeth well and appears to be fairly gentle. I have sensitive teeth and generally use toothpastes made for that issue but I bought this for the family and used it several times. It seemed fine to me. My son hated it. He said it tasted awful and didn't whiten his teeth like Crest or other super whitening toothpastes. I use activated charcoal to remove stains and whiten my teeth so I wasn't that worried about whether this paste would get my teeth sparking white. I just wanted a fresh mouth and well maintained teeth and this paste seems to do the job well enough. I prefer other brands for taste and formula but this one seems to do a good job and is often cheaper than other pastes of the same size.

I ate my bumble bee snack on the run for lunch along with an apple and it kept me going until dinner time which was amazing.  I guess it is the protein....anyway, the tuna is good, though I couldn't really discern rosemary, garlic or sea salt as dominating flavors, so if you are looking for a big flavor explosion, you won't get that.  What you will get is a nicely flavored tuna salad, much like you would make at home, not just a can of dry, flavored tuna.  My one drawback on this one was a small one.  Not enough crackers.  I had to really heap the tuna on the crackers-I believe there were 6 to use most of it and still ended up eating some out of the container, so a few more crackers would be good.  The crackers are Ritz like and go well with the tuna.  Other than not enough of them, they went well with the kit.

Overall, I would purchase this in this flavor or others to keep as a quick pack to take on a hike, eat as an emergency lunch or to just have on hand.  Very handy, very compact and a nice protein packed snack.
summary: Not enough crackers, but liked the tuna!

The first cookie I had, I was like, "What the hell is this texture?" It was dry, crumbly, chewy. But it had a lot of dark chocolate chips, so I persisted. The second cookie, I was, "Oh, this isn't so bad." By the third cookie a few days later, it seems my tongue acclimated to this texture and could appreciate this for what it is: a healthier cookie.

I must say, I enjoy them now. I think I had to get the idea of Oreos/ChipsAhoy/Tate's/Etc type cookies out of my brain and expect a healthier cookie, not a junk cookie. Expectations matter. Imagine if you are going to take a sip of cocoa, but it turns out there's tea in the cup. Your mouth doesn't like what it just tasted, because of expectations.

These are actually pretty good. Just get "cookie" out of your head and think "chewy high fiber chocolatey treat."  It's 4 grams of fiber per cookie and very little saturated fat and a it's a good-sized cookie (130 cals per). You only need ONE with your coffee or tea or cocoa to feel satisfied. And, really, so chock full of chips that every bite has that hit of choco-yumminess. Nice.

I am ordering another few boxes.

Update: I ordered two 3-packs and they are good through May of 2018, so they are fresh. And yumsy. I didn't like the oatmeal raisin ones, but these are good.
summary: It grows on you if you expect what it is, not what you think a cookie ought to be :) Yum.

reviewText:
I usually like most Kashi products, so I thought I would give these oatmeal chocolate chip cookies a whirl.  They are a good sized soft cookie and you can break them off in smaller bits and not have them crumble.  Just sweet enough, but not so sugar sweet as many store-bought cookies.  You can also definitely feel the chew of the oatmeal and the chocolate doesn't have that cheap taste.  I honestly enjoyed them, enough that I had trouble just stopping with one.

Yes, these cookies are soft, but if you want them to stay that way you have to seal them back up again if possible once you open the package.  An old fashioned cookie tin would be just the thing, or even a sealable bag.

I wouldn't say these are the absolute best oatmeal chocolate chip cookie I've ever had--that remains in the realm of home-made cookies, specifically a "secret" recipe taught to me by a relative--but if you aren't into spending an afternoon baking cookies and need to grab a box of more than decent cookies to take with, then this might be the one for you.  You pays for what you gets.
summary: A Better Made Oatmeal Choc Chip Cookie

reviewText: This is a thick cookie loaded with nuts and dark chocolate as well as other 'good' for me ingredients since it is from Kashi. It is filling. It is also very flavorful and yummy.

These are natural, and not organic. But they are tasty and a better choice than most regular name brands. If you can't find or afford organic, natural is always better - no artificial colors or flavors, no high fructose corn syrup, no chemical ingredients. Kashi does have a cloudy past with GMOs, however.

Overall, I'm pretty pleased with these cookies. The chocolate flavor comes through very well with no artificial undertones as is often the case with store-bought chocolate chip cookies. The cookies themselves are nicely sized - there are 8 per box. The cookies come in a tray and are not individually wrapped.

The cookie flavor itself was pretty good. I like the soft texture, although there is some grittiness due to the oatmeal and fiber. Not objectionable, however. What I didn't care for was how crumbly they are - they can easily fall apart.

But other than that one issue, a very good "better for you" type of oatmeal and chocolate cookie.
summary: Great chocolate taste; bit on the crumbly side

reviewText: This is the first time I've tried Kashi cookies, and I plan to get them again. The cookie is not the same as the picture on the box- there isn't as much fruit, for example- but the taste is pleasant and not as cloyingly rich as other cookies I've tried. If you want a healthy cookie, this may not be the one, I noticed the ingredients label indicated no nutrition. But one cookie is enough for a serving. Another caution is that there are only 8 cookies in a box, but they are double the size of typical cookies.
these are pretty tasty but i don't feel they are quite what I was looking for so I went to the happy trail mix cookies as an alternative

I think the biggest downside is that they are relatively expensive, with only 8 cookies per box.

TIP: Try them with some peanut butter spread on top.

reviewText: Great side for any dish.

With work, a new baby (16 months) and all, we're a real busy couple. Meals can be a problem. One of our solutions is to keep a goodly stock of Pasta Roni (Herbs and angle hair pasta is our favorite) in our pantry. We can fix up a batch in a matter of minutes, add a vegetable or and meat (heated in the microwave, of course) and the Pasta Roni makes up a nice complimentary side dish. It's not gourmet fare but it's quick and easy. Very handy product.

Gary Peterson

Ok, what's not to love about a meal you can make in about 10 minutes, tastes darn good, and is light on the wallet? It's not Italian carry-out by a long stretch, but it gets the job done. I'm a fan of this flavor, although my wife prefers the Garlic & Olive Oil Vermicelli. One complaint: the angel hair pasta will start to clump together if you don't eat it right away, and as leftovers it also tends to congeal if left too long in the fridge. Over all, this is an easy, cheap, and tasty-enough meal. If you're sick of Ramen, buy some.

It almost tastes homemade. It is creamy and quite hard to resist. Which is a problem because it is high in calories and fat and pretty low in any sort of real nutrition. It has a lot of junk ingredients too but man, oh, man, now and then it is worth the extra calories to dig in and enjoy this cheap and easy side dish. I always look for things that are healthy and low in fat and this really is neither but life isn't black or white. Now and then, I want some good macaroni and cheese and I don't want to spend time making it from scratch. I don't eat this often but I totally enjoy it when I do. Then I diet for two days after! I do use 2% milk instead of whole milk and it tastes just as good so I save on calories and fat a bit doing that. Skim milk waters down the taste. This is one of the tastiest boxed pasta mixes I have tried.

reviewText: Very happy to find this soup at the pantry at such a good price. It's almost double in price at stores around here. Great to have on hand here in the northeast with colder weather soon upon us.

This review is from: Progresso Rich & Hearty Soup, Chicken Pot Pie Style, 18.5-Ounce Cans (Pack of 12) (Grocery)
I take one star off of this soup only because the calories are higher than I like to see in a bowl of soup. This is 150 calories per serving, and I prefer the calories to be closer to 100. Of course this isn't advertised as a light soup either. My wife recently tried combining a can of this with a can of the Light Chicken and Dumpling. The result was a pleasing lunch at an average of only 115 calories per bowl.

There is no question that this is a good tasting soup. We used to be strictly Campbell's customers, but discovered many Progresso soups earlier this year as we explored alternatives which would complement our new style of eating (losing weight instead of gaining weight! LOL). To our delight we found, on average, Progresso soups seem to be lower calorie, lower sodium, and better flavored than Campbells. There are a couple of Campbell's that we still like better (New England Clam Chowder, for example) but other than just a few exceptions Progresso has the bulk of our soup business now.

Sadly, Amazon has recently raised their prices on all Progresso soups. Last summer and fall they were considerably more cost effective to buy 12 at a time on Amazon. Now the Amazon prices are quite similar to the prices at the upscale super-market we patronize. Even the Subscribe and Save prices are not currently much of a deal compared to buying locally, and locally we don't have to buy a case at a time. Be sure to compare your local prices to these prices before you order here. Also, make sure you are getting free shipping or you will pay more. Finally, be very wary of buying food products from Amazon Resellers. Their prices are normally extremely high compared to local markets, plus they will always have shipping added.
summary: Good soup, but the calories are a bit high

reviewText:
I just ate a whole can of this by myself, I didn't really stop to think how many servings were in the can.

I generally dislike canned soups, but Progresso makes decent ones.

This one was rather light on the beef, but what was there was of very good quality, tender and no gristle or fat.
The vegetables, especially the potatoes were perfectly cooked, making me wonder how Progresso can manage to put perfectly cooked veggies in their soups, but other brands are not able to.

The flavor was very nice, with none of the off notes that I have tasted in other ready to eat soups (Campbells, shudder, yuk)

I like to add a little oomph to canned soup, for this flavor I added a dash of red wine and some fresh ground pepper, really made the taste super good.
summary: Better than most other canned soups, try adding some red wine and fresh ground pepper!

reviewText:
While I normally prefer the full sodium soups, I really do like this Progresso minestrone soup as well (though I sneak in a bit more salt or I mix it with another can of a full sodium soup).  Like most canned soups, I primarily use this as a "base" soup and then add a little leftover rice or pasta and any fresh or frozen vegetables (like spinach) I have laying around.  This soup is pretty expensive in NYC supermarkets when not on sale ($3/can), so at less than $1.25 a can here and delivery right to my door, this is a bargain!

------UPDATE: 8-28-13-------

You gotta love Amazon.  When I received this order, they accidentally sent me the regular (full sodium, higher fat) version of this soup, which I did not want.  Although Amazon does not allow returns on supermarket food items, they issued me a credit right away. Way to go Amazon!

This is a very good tasting soup. Unlike many canned soups it's not excessively salty. Granted, you won't feel the need to add salt, but it's reasonably well balanced with regard to salt.

It is a bit on the thin side. While the term "hearty" is in the title, I don't think it reaches that mark, with a lot of broth present. The meat, while tasty, is in very small pieces.  The veggies are sparse and somewhat mushy. On the plus side, the potatoes are cut large and are of good consistency -- soft, but not mushy.

I find it works best with the addition of some beans, more veggies and/or some wild rice. Additions dial up the "hearty-ness" while preserving the overall good taste.

I picked this up to round out a recent Amazon Pantry order, but I would certainly buy it again.

reviewText: Good Stuff

If you're gonna make Macaroni and Cheese from a box, this is the way to go.  Velveeta Shells and Cheese can be prepared very quickly and has a very creamy taste.  That's because you're actually using the cheese sauce Velveeta is famous for and not that powdered stuff common with other boxes.  You will only need to boil water, put the shells in and cook until tender.  Once you drain the water, squeeze in the cheese and (I recommend) let it set for a few minutes, so the cheese can set.  I also enhance the flavor a bit by adding some sharp cheese.  I can't make enough for my preschooler.  We all love it!
This is an easy side dish for nights we grill burgers or steaks.  The cheese sauce is very good and makes a thicker sauce than that powdery stuff.

According to consumer reports, rice grown in California has the lowest levels of arsenic, however brown rice has the highest levels of arsenic because of the higher concentrations in the bran or the rice.  My family eats a lot of rice and the more I read about arsenic levels in rice the more concerned I became and I was happy to find out that there is rice available from areas that are fairly reliable when it comes to lower arsenic levels, but I remain concerned about the levels in all brown rices.  Lundberg brown basmati rice has always been very tasty and aromatic but we will eat less of it, while I wait for more research to come out about the harmful effects of higher arsenic levels vs the benefits of brown over white rice. Lundberg more than any other rice grower has responded with concern and is doing their own research into lowering arsenic levels in the rice, which I appreciate as a consumer.  I'm still giving this 4 stars because it is superior over other brands.

Edit:  I should mention that according to consumer reports Lundberg's brown rice has lower levels of arsenic than many other brands of white rice.
summary: Aromatic and tasty brown rice, but we will eat less brown rice in general due to arsenic level concerns

reviewText: They're good for you - a great snack to put almond butter, cheese etc. on & you'll enjoy it!!

These rice cakes are healthy in that they are organic and not filled with a lot of processed junk. They don't have much fiber at all and no discernable amount of vitamins as they are not enriched. They taste fine for what they are. I generally like the sweeter rice cakes as a healthy snack but I bought these to use as a sort of bread replacement. I put tuna or a few slices of turkey breast on one and the crunch is a great way to slow me down and actually get me to chew and enjoy my food. I usually eat super fast and don't even taste what I am eating. I like these but will probably see if they offer any sweetened ones like apple. I prefer them as a snack. Although they aren't packed with vitamins or fiber, they also aren't packed with a lot of chemicals so it's a good trade off in my mind.
